- Tea: green (seafood/salad), oolong (pork/dim sum), black/Assam (steak/chocolate), jasmine (spicy), lapsang (smoky BBQ).
- Coffee: light roast (citrus pastries), medium (nutty desserts), dark (chocolate, grilled meats).
- Mocktails/sodas: citrus lifts fried foods; ginger beer complements savory/spicy; tonic’s bitterness cuts fat.

Practical tips
- Serve from lighter to heavier, drier to sweeter.
- Keep drinks cold for crispness; warmth softens acidity and bubbles.
- Use water between bites to reset your palate.
- Personal preference beats any rule—adjust sweetness, acidity, and bitterness to taste.

Cone dribbling patterns (8–10 minutes)

- Slalom time between cones.
- 1-touch pass streak off the wall.
- Film short clips to check posture and touch.

Small-space options (home/in hallway)
- Use a futsal/size-1/tennis ball for tight touches.
- Foundations, toe taps, V-pulls, and wall passes in a few meters of space.

- “Gates” passing through small gaps; narrow the gate as you improve.

- Table Pictionary: Sketch on napkins or a phone notes app; teammates guess the word or phrase.

- After use, shake off water and let it dry fully while open in a ventilated spot. Don’t store it wet (prevents rust, mildew, and odor).
- Rinse after grit, sand, or saltwater exposure (like near rivers/coasts). Use fresh water, then dry thoroughly.
- Clean fabric with mild soap and water; avoid harsh detergents or machine washing. For mildew, wipe with diluted white vinegar, then rinse and dry.
- Restore water‑repellency occasionally with a DWR/silicone fabric spray once the canopy is clean and dry.
- Protect the frame: wipe ribs and joints dry; a light silicone spray on the hinges prevents rust and sticky action. Check and tighten small screws if present.
- Handle care: don’t use it as a cane. Keep wooden handles dry and occasionally oil them lightly; avoid leaving any umbrella in a hot car where glue can soften.
- Close it neatly: align the panels along their creases and secure the strap—no tight twisting. Use the sleeve/case for storage and pack it where it won’t be crushed.
- Inspect after strong gusts: if a rib bends, gently straighten it; replace missing tips or caps promptly (cheap repair kits are available).

Follow these and your umbrella should stay reliable through many rainy days.

chat.prompt: You are a helpful multimodal chat assistant. You are given an image, which is your first-person view of the real-world context you are situated in. The user query is: What are some important techniques to take some good photos with my camera?
chat.safe_output:
Great photos come from light, timing, and control. Here’s a quick, practical checklist you can use with almost any camera:

Light
- Look for soft light: windows, shade, golden hour. Turn off harsh overheads; mixed bulbs + window light can cause weird color.
- Avoid pointing the camera at bare bulbs (like those above the mirror)—they blow out and lower contrast. Move, reframe, or expose for the subject and keep lights out of frame.
- If using flash, bounce it off a wall/ceiling or diffuse; avoid direct on‑camera flash.

Exposure basics (the triangle)
- Aperture: wide (f/1.8–4) for blurred backgrounds/portraits; narrower (f/8–11) for landscapes.
- Shutter speed: freeze action at ~1/500–1/1000; for people handheld aim ≥1/125. As a rule, keep speed at least 1/focal length.
- ISO: keep low for clean images; raise it in low light rather than letting the shutter get too slow.

Focus and sharpness
- Use single‑point AF on the eye for portraits; continuous AF for moving subjects.
- Stabilize: two hands, elbows tucked; brace on a wall/doorframe, or use a tripod. Use a 2‑sec timer/remote to avoid shake.
- Clean the lens; use a lens hood to reduce flare.

Composition
- Simplify the background; watch for distractions or bright hotspots.
- Rule of thirds, leading lines, symmetry, and negative space all help. Move your feet, change height, and fill the frame.
- Keep horizons straight; leave headroom and avoid objects “growing” from people’s heads.

Color and exposure control
- Set white balance to match the light (daylight/shade/tungsten) or shoot RAW and fix later.
- Use exposure compensation (+/−) and the histogram to protect highlights (dial − when bright areas clip).

Quick starting points
- Indoor portrait by a window: Aperture Priority, f/2.8–4, Auto ISO (cap ~1600–3200), min shutter 1/125, face the window.
- Outdoor landscape: f/8, ISO 100, focus a third into the scene.
- Action: Shutter Priority 1/1000, Auto ISO, continuous AF and burst mode.

Self‑portrait tip for here
- Skip the mirror shot: place the camera on a shelf/tripod near the window, turn off the vanity lights, use a timer/remote, and step away from the wall for nicer light and background separation.

Practice: shoot, review, and adjust one variable at a time. Take multiples, then compare what changed.

- Straighten the wheels, adjust forward/back to center in the space, and end 6–12 in from the curb.

- Start a little farther out from the lead car (closer to 3–4 ft) to create a sharper entry angle.
- Use small “shuffles”: back in until near the car behind, then pull forward while turning away from the curb; repeat once or twice to square up.

- Use mirrors/camera, look over your right shoulder, and stop if you lose sight of the curb.
- If you lightly touch the curb, pull forward a foot and correct—don’t ride up on it.

- Buffalo: males have a broad horn “boss” across the forehead; females’ horns are narrower and lack the full boss.
- Antelope/gazelle: both sexes may have horns; males’ are usually thicker/longer and more ridged. For deer, antlers are typically male-only (except reindeer).
- Warthogs: males have larger tusks and bigger facial “warts.”
- Ostrich: males are black-and-white; females are brown/gray.
- Hippos/rhinos: males have larger, blockier heads; females are often with calves. Genitals are hard to see from afar, so behavior and size help most.

How to observe safely from your car
- Keep a safe distance; do not block animals or separate mothers and young.
- Stay inside the vehicle; keep windows mostly up around predators or pushy species.
- Use binoculars/zoom instead of edging closer.
- Move on if animals approach too closely or show agitation (staring, mock charges, tail swishing, head shaking).
- Follow all park instructions; never feed or call animals.

If you point out a specific animal you’re looking at, I can help you apply these cues in real time.

Quick safety note: you’re in heavy traffic. Only try this if you’re a passenger or fully pulled off the road in a safe, legal spot. Never stop suddenly for wildlife.

General cues you can use from a car (not all apply to every species):
- Size and build: males are often larger with thicker necks/shoulders (e.g., deer, elk, cattle, horses). In many birds of prey, females are larger.
- Ornamentation: antlers (deer/elk/moose = males; antlers are shed seasonally), manes (lions), bright plumage (many male ducks, pheasants, songbirds), larger horns/ruff (male sheep/goats, though both sexes may have horns).
- Reproductive anatomy: udders/visible teats (females in many mammals), scrotum or sheath (males). Only use this if it’s clearly visible and you’re at a safe distance.
- Behavior: males may display, sing, or posture more; females may be with young. In canids, males often lift a leg to urinate while females crouch (not 100% reliable).

Fast tips for common roadside animals:
- Deer/Elk/Moose: antlers = male (outside of late winter when shed). Males have thicker necks/chests; females often with fawns/calves.
- Cattle: horns don’t prove sex. Bulls have a heavy neck/shoulders and visible scrotum; cows have an udder; steers lack an udder and have smaller necks.
- Sheep/Goats: both sexes can have horns; rams/bucks usually have bigger, thicker horns; males may have a stronger shoulder/neck and, in goats, a more pronounced beard.
- Horses: stallions/geldings show a sheath; mares have an udder near the hind legs; stallions often heavier-necked.
- Ducks: drakes are brightly colored in breeding season; females are mottled/brown. Geese sexes look similar; size and behavior help.
- Raptors: females are typically larger; plumage often similar—size and voice can help.

Limits: juveniles and nonbreeding seasons can make sexing hard; don’t rely on a single cue.

Gear and apps: binoculars, camera with zoom; apps like Merlin Bird ID, iNaturalist, or a local mammal guide.

Distance/ethics: give wildlife plenty of space (25+ m for most animals; 100+ m for large mammals), don’t honk or feed, and obey local laws.
